repnme.cdata!: Egypt - Small and Medium Scale Industry Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Small and Medium Scale Industry (SMI)
            Project in Egypt. The project aimed to support the
            development of SMIs in the private sector through financial
            and technical assistance. Industrial Development Bank of
            Egypt(IDBE), which is fully owned by the Government of Egypt
            (GOE), has been serving as a development finance institution
            (DFI) to promote and finance particularly the development of
            small and medium industries (SMIs) in the private sector.
            The Project, even though substantially delayed, was able to
            help improve the operations of IDBE from the state they were
            in when the loan was made in the mid-1980s. One important
            lesson learned in this project is the success of a DFI
            operation depends to a significant extent on the financial
            intermediary strengthening its capability for project
            appraisal, supervision, and follow-up with adequate
            provision for training. The Bank has indicated that it would
            be willing to consider providing funds under an apex loan in
            the future if IDBE is restructured by allowing equity
            participation by private investors, enabling it to function
            as an independent entity. IDBE is also considering the
            option of raising funds by issuing bond.

repnme.cdata!: Egypt - Small- and Medium-Scale Industry Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Small and Medium Scale Industry
            (SMI) Project is designed to support the program for the
            development of SMI through a line of credit to DIB and
            technical assistance to individual enterprises.  It provides
            a part of DIB's foreign exchange requirements over
            1985-87 for onlending to SMI, with special emphasis on
            small-scale industries (SSI).  It  also finances the foreign
            exchange cost of continuing the program of technical
            assistance to SMI begun under previous loans.  The project
            provides further support for the Governments'
            "open-door" policy.  By providing financial
            assistance to SMI, it contributes to the development of this
            important part of the private sector, while the technical
            assistance component increases the productivity and
            efficiency of SMI.  The project is expected to create about
            71,000 new jobs.
